posts.name:
Jenn Drummond
Jenn Drummond
posts.content:
It’s cool when someone says my talks are .

But that’s not my favorite feedback. What matters most?

Hearing things like: “Now I know what to do.” or...
“Others talk about it, but you show 𝘦𝘹𝘢𝘤𝘵𝘭𝘺 how to do it.”

(Direct quotes from yesterday.)

Give people something they can 𝘶𝘴𝘦.

2 attendees approached me after my recent talk.
Both had already tried what I shared.
And both had results.

One even joked: “Seriously, I’ll have to send you some money soon!”

(For the record, my new friend can keep his kind offer.)

What I want you to remember is:

It’s easy to feel warm and fuzzy about learning.
But unless you go deploy it - you’re wasting potential.

Here’s the hierarchy:

Action → Notes → Listening → Attending

Take it all in. But don’t stop there.

Go 𝘥𝘰 𝘴𝘰𝘮𝘦𝘵𝘩𝘪𝘯𝘨. That’s where the magic happens.

P.S. Ever received a compliment on LinkedIn from someone that made your entire day?

comments.commentText:
Jenn Drummond. I couldn't agree more! I love knowing that I helped inspire you. But the most impactful feedback I get is when it happens the next day... OR the next month! "I still remember what you said and I'm working towards it!" 

Inspiration evaporates
Impact is what the change in action you now feel empowered to take.

I'd LOVE to see you in action if the opportunity presents itself!

Joseph Cope, M. Ed  Absolutely! That long-term impact is the real win. 

Hearing how something resonates over time is the best.

Jenn Drummond I had the chance to explore your profile and I was amazed by your remarkable journey and contributions. I’d be honored to share your story and feature your biography in a reputable magazine through PR Words. Let’s connect to discuss this exciting opportunity

Ayesha karamat Thank you so much for your kind words!

I’d love to connect and hear more about this exciting opportunity. Let’s chat soon!

posts.commentAdded: Absolutely! Learning is just the first step; putting it into action is where transformation happens. Love your approach to engagement! 👏 #ActionMatters

posts.name:
Lucas Wilson
Lucas Wilson
posts.content:
How do you make game-changing tech accessible to every SMB?

At Signpost, our vision has always been to empower SMB entrepreneurs to thrive, no matter their size or budget. That vision is becoming reality as we prepare to launch a 100% self-service AI solution that will redefine communication for businesses.

This isn’t just about technology—it’s about removing barriers and meeting SMBs where they are. Whether business is booming or slow, this tool scales with their needs, offering unmatched flexibility and value.

Stay tuned for more details as we count down to January 29th. The future of SMB communication is here, and it’s faster, smarter, and more accessible than ever.

Sydney Andersen I honestly can’t wait!

posts.commentAdded: Exciting times ahead! Empowering SMBs with cutting-edge tech is a game changer. Cant wait for the launch on January 29th! 🚀 #Innovation

posts.name:
Brian Nichols
Brian Nichols
posts.content:
The best founders aren’t know-it-alls. They’re learn-it-alls.

When you’re building a startup, there’s always a moment when you realize what got you here won’t get you there.

Problems evolve. Stakes get higher. And suddenly, you’re in completely uncharted waters.

This is when the “learning founder” shines.

Three things set them apart…

1️⃣ They ask great questions. Instead of pretending to know, they ask:
️ “What am I missing?”
️ “Who’s done this before?”
️ “What’s the real problem here?”

2️⃣ They surround themselves with experts. Learning founders know when to say, “I don’t have all the answers, but I can find people who do.” They lean on mentors, peers and even competitors to accelerate growth.

3️⃣ They learn faster than anyone else. They treat every mistake, failure and setback as data. Instead of getting defensive, they become curious.
This is a huge deal, because in startups, your speed of learning determines your speed of progress.

The “learning founder” will out-execute, out-innovate and outlast those who try to fake it.

So ask yourself:
️ What’s one skill, insight, or area you need to level up in right now?
️ Who can you learn it from?

Remember: It’s not about having all the answers, all the time, it’s about your ability to find them.

comments.commentText:
One thing I'm struggling with is the best approach to scaling API-led LLM integrations (largely from a cost perspective). 

Not struggling with the HOW - more so struggling with WHICH HOW? There don't appear to be any charted waters on how to do it sustainably. We are doing some research internally.

That said, I couldn't agree with your post more. Speed can't be forced, it must be learned. Defensiveness is the speed-killer, as it actively prevents learning. We try really hard to kill our defensiveness when we work with each other at

posts.commentAdded: Absolutely! Embracing a growth mindset is key for founders. Continuous learning truly fuels innovation and resilience. Great insights! 🔑📚

posts.name:
Jennifer Bleam, Sales Sherpa
Jennifer Bleam, Sales Sherpa
posts.content:
Your demo sucks - and it's costing you money. 
 
(oops – I said the quiet part out loud again.)

Your demo isn’t about you or your solution.

It’s about your prospect and their problems.

(Hint: “Demo” means “demonstration”. Your job is to demonstrate how you solve the prospect’s problem.)

The biggest mistake sellers make? Talking about every single feature of their solution.

Spoiler alert: prospects don’t care about 90% of them. They care about the one thing that solves their pain.

Professional sellers find out what the PROSPECT cares about and then demonstrate how they can help.

And if your solution can’t solve their problem, then they aren’t a prospect.

That’s fine!

Move on to the next person.

Demos are about demonstrating, NOT about talking your prospect to death.
posts.commentAdded: Spot on! Focusing on the prospects needs is crucial. A targeted demo can transform interest into a genuine solution. Great insights!

posts.name:
Sudhansu Padhy
Sudhansu Padhy
posts.content:
It was an enriching experience sharing my thoughts on "Future-Ready Skills for Vikshit Bharat 2047: Preparing for the Next Big Leap" with the enthusiastic young minds of Purnima University.
The energy, curiosity, and passion displayed by the students were truly inspiring. Interacting with them reaffirmed my belief in the potential of our youth to drive innovation and lead India towards a brighter future.
I wish all the students the very best for their future endeavors and I am confident they will excel in shaping the India of tomorrow!! I asked them what is the rating you will give my session out of five and they all have given the feedback captured nicely in a photo by one of the student volunteers.
I brought a lot of positive vibes with me... thanks to my mentors for choosing me for the session

comments.commentText: Thank you for such an insightful session sir. Your expertise and clear explanation truly added value to our understanding. Looking forward to learning more from you in the future!

posts.commentAdded: What a fantastic initiative! Your passion for guiding the next generation is truly commendable. Excited to see them shape India’s future! 🌟

My secret Mantra as a Senior PM:

“Never tell people how to do things. Tell them what to do, and they will surprise you with their ingenuity.”

comments.commentText: Follow Pranali Jouras for more such updates
The leaders who can inspire others with their trust and can enable others to trust them, do justice to their role. Pranali Jouras

posts.name:
Rich McDaniel jr.
Rich McDaniel jr.
posts.content:
I’m close to the end of a 2-year non compete. 

Personally, it doesn’t affect me anymore, but makes me think:

It’s so important to choose your partner, employer, boss, friends, etc carefully.

Don’t rush into anything.
Vet people carefully.
Weigh options.

You’ll be glad you did.


️️

comments.commentText:
Agree!

Good things come to those who wait and choose carefully.

posts.commentAdded: Great insights! Taking the time to choose the right partners and opportunities can truly lead to long-term success. Well said!
